stories.text:
I've finally become proficient with Tailwind CSS.

However, my sites still look ok. I've adopted the idea of "use different shades gray to make UIs" and, as a result, my sites look... professional but uninviting.

Consider sites like:

- https://curius.app/

- https://www.notion.so/

- https://www.focusmate.com/

These sites look warm and inviting. Being proficient with Tailwind CSS just helps me have good padding, margins, and a reasonable default color scheme. It doesn't help me make my site look... human.

I feel like I need a "design palette" instead of a mere "color/margin palette". What's the recommendation for this?
stories.title: Ask HN: Design palettes instead of color palettes?
NashStore: Russia's alternative to the Google Play store
The bombsight eye: envisioning nuclear war
Lots of Data, but Uncertainty About What to Do with It

stories.text:
I like to think I can manage boredom with my smartphone. I mindlessly scroll social media and get my giggles when I'm bored. But it has a law of diminishing returns. Eventually I just get sick of social media and the Internet in general. It doesn't spark the same joy. I walk a good distance everyday which helps & gets me back into creative mode when I need to work on a side project.

Like what even is boredom? I've looked it up, but the term for me is a lot deeper. I get very deep boredom or extreme boredom to the point I have to go outside for a walk just to do something, even if there is no goal other than to walk.

What do you do, to defeat boredom? I'd like to hear your thoughts!
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you handle boredom?
Beyond Message Passing: A Physics-Inspired Paradigm for Graph Neural Networks
